title: 110_s2006
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" and provides disaster assistance for power transmission and distribution facilities. The "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" amends the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to define a private or investor-owned power facility as a transmission or distribution facility providing electric or natural gas service to retail customers under State or local jurisdiction, including leased facilities. Conditions for contributions are also revised. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to allow contributions to private or investor-owned power facilities damaged by a major disaster for repair and associated expenses. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to allow assistance for private or investor-owned power facilities damaged by a major disaster, including restoration, reconstruction, or replacement of the facility and associated expenses. Conditions for assistance include defining a "previous major disaster" as one occurring within 10 years before the current disaster declaration. The President may provide assistance to private or investor-owned power facilities damaged by a major disaster, but only if the cost of repairs from the previous disaster exceeded $2,500 per customer. Private or investor-owned power facilities damaged by a major disaster may receive assistance from the President if repair costs from the previous disaster exceeded $2,500 per customer and total costs exceeded $500,000,000. Private or investor-owned power facilities meeting specific criteria, such as having a significant portion of the population below the Federal poverty level after a major disaster, are eligible to apply for Federal assistance within 30 days of a disaster declaration. Private or investor-owned power facilities meeting specific criteria can apply for Federal assistance within 30 days of a disaster declaration or after contributing $10,000,000 towards repair costs. Federal assistance is limited for disaster relief. Federal assistance for disaster relief to private or investor-owned power facilities is limited to costs exceeding $10,000,000. Costs from previous major disasters within a 12-month period will be aggregated for determination. The President must approve or disapprove assistance applications within 30 days. The President must approve or disapprove assistance applications for private or investor-owned power facilities within 30 days. The Federal Share under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is expanded to include private or investor-owned power facilities. The Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to allow private or investor-owned power facilities to receive a contribution equal to 75 percent of the Federal estimate for repairs or replacement, under certain conditions. Private or investor-owned power facilities can receive a contribution equal to 75 percent of the Federal estimate for repairs or replacement. The funds can be used for repairing, restoring, expanding, or constructing power facilities, as well as for hazard mitigation measures. Private or investor-owned power facilities can receive a contribution equal to 75 percent of the Federal estimate for repairs or replacement. The funds can be used for repairing, restoring, expanding, or constructing power facilities, as well as for hazard mitigation measures. Additionally, eligible costs now include private or investor-owned power facilities under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. SEC. 3. REGULATIONS.

Within 180 days of enactment, the Secretary of Homeland Security must create regulations for implementing and amending this Act.

SEC. 4. EFFECTIVE DATE.

This Act and its amendments will take effect 60 days after enactment, with Section 3 taking effect immediately.
